newsitem.title: GERMANY: Lamfalussy says dollar correction now exaggerated.
newsitem.headline: Lamfalussy says dollar correction now exaggerated.

text.p: European Monetary Institute President Alexandre Lamfalussy said on Monday the dollar was showing an exaggerated correction of its previous imbalance against other currencies.

Lamfalussy told the Sueddeutsche Zeitung in an interview that the main force strengthening the dollar against the mark was the expectation of rising interest rates in the United States after a six-year economic upturn.
"In addition, exchange rate movements in floating systems tend to be too strong when they are correcting past imbalances. This is likely to be the case today with the dollar," Lamfalussy said.

The dollar has made strong gains against the mark as well as the Japanese yen recently. It was trading at 1.6935 marks in early European dealings, above the level of 1.65 marks at which the Group of Seven (G7) industrial nations said the dollar had been corrected.
The G7 statement was issued after a meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors in Berlin on February 8.
